question: Question_01_(g)
statement:
Answer the following multiple choice question. Check your answer very
carefully. Your answer will be marked right or wrong (work will not be
considered for this problem).

Which of the following is the closest approximation to the value of the
integral

\[\int_0^{1} \frac{1-\cos(x)} x \,dx\]

(Hint: use Taylor series)

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
A. 1
\end{description}

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
B. 1/4
\end{description}

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
C. 1/2
\end{description}

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
D. 5/6
\end{description}
sols:
The Taylor expansion of cos(\emph{x}) is

\[\cos(x) = 1- \frac{x^2}{2!} + \frac{x^4}{4!} +\cdots = 1- \frac{x^2}2 + \frac{x^4}{24}+ \cdots\]

Keeping the terms up to \emph{x}\textsuperscript{2}, we get

\[\frac{1-\cos(x)}{x} \approx \frac{ x^2/2}{x} = \frac{x}{2}\]

Therefore

\[\int_0^1 \frac{1-\cos(x)} x \,dx \approx \int_0^1 \frac{x}{2} \,dx = \left.\frac{x^2}{4}\right|_0^1 = 1/4\]

So 1/4 is a good approximation. Note that taking more terms of the
Taylor expansions of cos(\emph{x}) would simply yield an even better
approximation.
hints:
Recall the Taylor series of cos(\emph{x}) and use just the first two
terms for a simplification of the integrand.
